div.sent: Compounds are divided on the basis of their chemical properties.
Three such classes are acids, bases and salts.
There are similarities among the properties of different compounds that belong to the same class.
Acid is an English word.
All the substances with a sour taste contain acid.
Tamarind, lemon, tomatoes, orange, citrus fruits, curd, vinegar etc. contain organic acids.
These are weak acids and they are not harmful.
But some acids used in laboratories are very strong.
Usually, hydrochloric acid, sulphuric acid and nitric acid- these three acids are widely used in laboratories and in various chemical industries.
These acids are inorganic or mineral acids.
Now the question is what is acid?
Acid reacts with bases to produce salt and water.
Acid has a sour test and it turns blue litmus red.
Take 4-5 test tubes.
Take 2-3 drops of vinegar, lemon juice, tomato or orange juice, tamarind solution and curd water in each tube.
Now perform the following tests and note the result down in the table.
Take three acids which are used in laboratories.
Write down the names and formulaof these acids.
Observe the formula of acids very minutely.
There is a common element in all the acid containing other different elements.
Can you tell, what is the name of that common element?
This is hydrogen (H).
Now take a small piece of zinc in a test tube and add 2-3 drops of dilute hydrochloric acid in it.
What do you observe ?
Reaction starts vigorously and gas 44 General Science comes out in the form of bubbles.
Hold a lighted toper at the mouth of the test tube.
The gas begins to burn with a cracking sound.
Can you explain what has just happened?
Now think what is the name of the gas.
It is hydrogen.
Write down the equation of chemical reaction between zinc and hydrochloric acid.
From the above experiment we can come to the conclusion that all acids contain replaceable hydrogen atoms.
Acid reacts with metal to produce hydrogen.
When hydrochloric acid and sulphuric acid react with metals like zinc, magnesium and aluminium, they produce hydrogen.
It may be mentioned here that some metalslike copper and lead do not react in normal conditions with hydrochloric acid and sulphuric acid.
Again sodium (Na), potassium (K) and calcium (Ca) react vigorously with acids and these reactions are very dangerous.
For this, these metals are not used in laboratory for the preparation of hydrogen gas.
Now let us discuss the other properties or characteristics of acids.
Take some lime stone (CaCO3) in a test tube and add a few drops of hydrochloric acid in it.
What have you seen?
Reaction starts vigorously and gas comes out as bubbles.
Hold an ignited stick at the mouth of the test tube.
The ignited stick is extinguished immediately.
Now can you tell what gas was produced in this reaction?
The evolved gas is carbon dioxide.
It can be tested by another experiment.
Weknow carbon dioxide turns lime water milky.
Now take some clear lime water in a test tube and pass this gas through lime water.
What do you observe?
The clear lime water turns milky.
From this experimentwhat conclusion may we reach?
The gas produced is carbon dioxide.
One easy method to identify the acids is the use of indicators.
Acids and bases can easily be identified by using indicators.
An indicator is a chemical compound which changes its colour when it comes in contact with acids or bases.
From this change of colour we can identify which is acid or which is base, and which is neither acid nor base.
To identify the acids or bases usually three kinds of indicators viz.
litmus paper or litmus solution, methyl orange, phenolphthalein, etc. are used in the laboratory.
Besides this we may prepare similar ind cators from flowers and roots of plants.
Take four test tubes.Take 2-3 drops of dilute acid in each of them.
Mark these tubes by the numbers1,2,3 and Add 2-3 drops of litmus solution in the test tube number 1.
Similarly add 2-3 drops of phenolphthalein in test tube no 2.
2-3 drops of methyl orange in test tube 3 and add a few drops of joba flowers essence in test tube.
Observe the change of colour of these indicators as they come in contact with acid and write them in the table below.
Notice how the colour changes, (if any) due to the presence of each indicator and write your comments in the table.
Dilute aquaus solution of sulphuric acid turns blue litmus red.
Dilute sulphuric acid solution is sour to taste.
Therefore, from the above facts, it is proved that sulphuric acid is an acid.
Sulphuric acid is a strong acid.
If water is added to sulphuric acid to dilute it, the acid becomes very hot and starts boiling.
So never add water to acid in order to make dilute sulphuric acid.
Acid is added to water in small drops to dilute it.
Never taste sulphuric acid with mouth, no matter if it is dilute or concentrated.
One should be careful when working with hydrochloric acid, sulphuric acid, nitric acid, etc. so that they do not come in contact with one's skin.
The compounds having opposite properties of acids are known as bases.
When acid and base are combined together a new compound is formed.
It has neither the properties of acid nor that of base.
Acid and base react to form salt and water.
Usually, the oxides (compounds of metal and oxygen) and hydroxides (compounds of metal, oxygen and hydrogen) are called bases.
It is seen that the formula of the above compounds are oxides and hydroxides of metals.
These are bases.
Therefore, any oxide or hydroxide of a metal, which possesses the property of neutralising an acid to produce salt and water is called base.
Most of the bases are not soluble in water.
The bases which are soluble in water are called alkalis.
So, alkalis are special types bases which are soluble in water.
That is, all alkalis are bases but all bases are not alkalis.
For example, zinc oxide, sodium hydroxide, potassium hydroxide, iron hydroxide, copper hydroxide, etc. are bases.
Out of these, sodium hydroxide and potassium hydroxide are soluble in water.
These hydroxides are alkalis.
But iron and copper are insoluble in water.
So these two metal hydroxides are bases, but not alkalis.
Bases may or may not be soluble in water but alkalis are all soluble in water.
Take few drops of sodium hydroxide or potassium hydroxide in two test tubes and repeat the experiment no.
4.4 using different types of indicators.
Note down the results in similar tables.
Now perform the following experiments.
Take some lime water in a test tube and introduce red and blue litmus papers in it.
Observe the change of colour in the litmus paper.
You will see that the colour of red litmus paper in lime water has changed to blue.
Take the taste of the lime water.
It has acrid taste.
In this way soda or all other alkaline solutions turn red litmus blue and they taste acrid.
Take 20 ml sodium hydroxide solution in a beaker using a measuring cylinder.
Add 1-2 drops of phenolphthalein solution as an indicator.
You will see that the solution has turned into a nice pink colour.
Now add some drops of dilute hydrochloric acid with a dropper.
Stir the solution in beaker well and continue the addition of acid in drops.
A time will come when the pink solution will become colourless.
Write down the number of acid drops that are required to make 20 ml Solution colourless.
Sodium hydroxide is a strong alkali.
Can you tell why the colour of the indicator changed when hydrochloric acid was added to the sodium hydroxide solution?
The reason is that alkali and acid neutralize each other through a vigorous chemical reaction.
An indicator is not used in this stage.
Now, heat the colourless solution of acid and base until it dries up.
What do you find at the bottom of the beaker?
There is a white residue at the bottom of the beaker.
Take a little residue after cooling the beaker, and taste it.
What taste does it have?
It tastes salty?
Was there any chemical reaction?
If any chemical reaction occurs in this case, let us try to express the reaction by an equation.
From this experiment, it is understood that alkali reacts with acid to produce salt and water.
In most cases, when alkali is added to metallic salt solutions, metallic hydroxide is precipitated by a chemical reaction.
Take 2 ml of copper sulphate solution in a big test tube.
Add 1 ml of sodium hydroxide solution to it.
Precipitate is formed at the bottom of the test tube.
Can you tell what precipitate it is?
An aqueous solution of a base has a soapy touch or feeling.
An aqueous solution of a base conducts electricity.
Arguments for the statement: Sodium hydroxide is an alkali Sodium hydroxide is an alkali due to the following reasons:
The base sodium hydroxide is soluble in water.
Aqueous solution of sodium hydroxide turns red litmus blue.
When one drop of phenolphthalein is added to sodium hydroxide, the solution becomes pink.
One drop of methyl orange turns sodium hydroxide solution yellow.
Sodium hydroxide solution reacts with dilute acid solution vigorously to produce salt and water.
Some metal hydroxides are precipitated by adding sodium hydroxide.
The solution of sodium hydroxide has a soapy touch.
The above properties are the characteristics of alkali.
From the above arguments we can prove that sodium hydroxide is an alkali.
Salt is a special type of compound in chemistry.
Besides edible salt or sodium chloride, soda, blue vitriol etc. are also salts.
From each of the above examples, it is found that metallic part of alkali e.g.
Na, Zn, K etc. replaces hydrogen atom of the acid to form a new compound which is salt.
In the above examples Na, Zn, K, etc are basic radicals and Cl, SO4, NO3, etc are acid radicals.
So we can say, salts are composed of basic and acid radicals.
When acid is added to alkali solution, a vigorous reaction takes place.
As a result of such reaction both acid and alkali lose their properties and form new compounds, i.e. salt and water.
The chemical name of a salt is taken from the name of the acid or the base that produces it.
The name of the metal (basic part) is mentioned first and the name of the acid part comes next.
The salt which is produced by the reaction of hydrochloric acid is called chloride salt e.g.
Sodium chloride, Calcium chloride, Ammonium chloride etc.
The salt produced from sulphuric acid is called sulphate salt e,g sodium sulphate, copper sulphate, ammonium sulphate etc.
The salt of nitric acid is called nitrate salt e.g potassium nitrate copper nitrate, ammonium nitrate etc.
The salt of carbonic acid is called carbonate salt e.g.
sodium carbonate, calcium carbonate, ammonium carbonate etc.
The common names and chemical names of some salts which are used in our everyday life are; Take three beakers.
Now, take dilute hydrochloric acid, sodium hydroxide sodium chloride in the first, second and third beaker respectively.
All these three solutions are colourless.
Introduce blue litmus paper to the first beaker.
Litmus paper turns blue.
So, the solution in the first beaker is acid.
Introduce red litmus paper to the 2nd beaker.
Litmus turns blue.
So, the solution in 2nd beaker is alkali.
Introduce both red and blue litmus papers to the 3rd beaker.
No change of colour is noticed.
So, the solution of the 3rd beaker is a salt solution.
In the 3rd beaker you put sodium chloride solution.
Salt is neither acidic nor basic.
Salts are formed by the chemical reactions between acids and alkalis.
So, salts are usually neutral compounds.
Solution of sodium chloride is a neutral compound.
So sodium chloride solution does not change the colour of the indicator.
